<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Pete_Seeger skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Pete Seeger</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-protected&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-protected (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-protected</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_musical_artist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox musical artist (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox musical artist</a>
</p><p><b>Peter</b> "<b>Pete</b>" <b>Seeger</b> (May 3, 1919&#160;– January 27, 2014) was an American folk singer and activist. A fixture on nationwide radio in the 1940s, he also had a string of hit records during the early 1950s as a member of <a href="/wiki/The_Weavers" title="The Weavers">the Weavers</a>, most notably their recording of <a href="/wiki/Lead_Belly" title="Lead Belly">Lead Belly</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Goodnight,_Irene" title="Goodnight, Irene">Goodnight, Irene</a>", which topped the charts for 13 weeks in 1950. Members of the Weavers were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blacklist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blacklist (page does not exist)">blacklisted</a> during the <a href="/wiki/McCarthyism" title="McCarthyism">McCarthy Era</a>. In the 1960s, he re-emerged on the public scene as a prominent singer of <a href="/wiki/Protest_song" title="Protest song">protest music</a> in support of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_disarmament" title="Nuclear disarmament">international disarmament</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Civil_rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Civil rights (page does not exist)">civil rights</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Counterculture_of_the_1960s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Counterculture of the 1960s (page does not exist)">counterculture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Environmentalism" title="Environmentalism">environmental causes</a>.
</p><p>A prolific songwriter, his best-known songs include "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Where_Have_All_the_Flowers_Gone%3F&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Where Have All the Flowers Gone? (page does not exist)">Where Have All the Flowers Gone?</a>" (with <a href="/wiki/Joe_Hickerson" title="Joe Hickerson">Joe Hickerson</a>), "<a href="/wiki/If_I_Had_a_Hammer" title="If I Had a Hammer">If I Had a Hammer (The Hammer Song)</a>" (with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lee_Hays&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lee Hays (page does not exist)">Lee Hays</a> of the Weavers), and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Turn!_Turn!_Turn!_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turn! Turn! Turn! (song) (page does not exist)">Turn! Turn! Turn!</a>" (lyrics adapted from <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastes" title="Ecclesiastes">Ecclesiastes</a>), which have been recorded by many artists both in and outside the folk revival movement and are sung throughout the world. "Flowers" was a hit recording for <a href="/wiki/The_Kingston_Trio" title="The Kingston Trio">the Kingston Trio</a> (1962); <a href="/wiki/Marlene_Dietrich" title="Marlene Dietrich">Marlene Dietrich</a>, who recorded it in English, German and French (1962); and <a href="/wiki/Johnny_Rivers" title="Johnny Rivers">Johnny Rivers</a> (1965). "If I Had a Hammer" was a hit for <a href="/wiki/Peter,_Paul_%26_Mary" title="Peter, Paul &amp; Mary" class="mw-redirect">Peter, Paul &amp; Mary</a> (1962) and <a href="/wiki/Trini_Lopez" title="Trini Lopez">Trini Lopez</a> (1963), while <a href="/wiki/The_Byrds" title="The Byrds">the Byrds</a> had a number one hit with "Turn! Turn! Turn!" in 1965.
</p><p>Seeger was one of the folksingers most responsible for popularizing the spiritual "<a href="/wiki/We_Shall_Overcome" title="We Shall Overcome">We Shall Overcome</a>" (also recorded by <a href="/wiki/Joan_Baez" title="Joan Baez">Joan Baez</a> and many other singer-activists) that became the acknowledged anthem of the 1960s <a href="/w/index.php?title=African-American_Civil_Rights_Movement_(1955%E2%80%931968)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African-American Civil Rights Movement (1955–1968) (page does not exist)">American Civil Rights Movement</a>, soon after folk singer and activist <a href="/wiki/Guy_Carawan" title="Guy Carawan">Guy Carawan</a> introduced it at the founding meeting of the <a href="/wiki/Student_Nonviolent_Coordinating_Committee" title="Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee">Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee</a> (SNCC) in 1960. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=PBS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PBS (page does not exist)">PBS</a> <i><a href="/wiki/American_Masters" title="American Masters">American Masters</a></i> episode "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Pete_Seeger:_The_Power_of_Song&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (page does not exist)">Pete Seeger: The Power of Song</a>", Seeger stated it was he who changed the lyric from the traditional "We will overcome" to the more singable "We shall overcome".
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family_and_personal_life">Family and personal life</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Renehan_Seeger_March2008.jpg" title="File:Renehan Seeger March2008.jpg">File:Renehan Seeger March2008.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Pete Seeger (right), 88 years old, photographed in March 2008 with his friend, the writer and musician <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edward_J._Renehan,_Jr.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edward J. Renehan, Jr. (page does not exist)">Ed Renehan</a></div></div></div>
<p>Seeger was born at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=French_Hospital_(Manhattan)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="French Hospital (Manhattan) (page does not exist)">French Hospital</a>, Midtown Manhattan.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> His Yankee-Protestant family, which Seeger called "enormously Christian, in the <a href="/wiki/Puritan" title="Puritan">Puritan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Calvinist" title="Calvinist" class="mw-redirect">Calvinist</a> New England tradition",<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> traced its genealogy back over 200 years. A paternal ancestor, Karl Ludwig Seeger, a physician from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kingdom_of_W%C3%BCrttemberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kingdom of Württemberg (page does not exist)">Württemberg</a>, Germany, had emigrated to America during the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a> and married into an old New England family in the 1780s.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
Pete's father, the <a href="/wiki/Harvard" title="Harvard" class="mw-redirect">Harvard</a>-trained composer and musicologist<sup id="cite_ref-pc1_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc1-4">[4]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Louis_Seeger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Louis Seeger (page does not exist)">Charles Louis Seeger, Jr.</a>, was born in Mexico City, Mexico, to American parents. Charles established the first musicology curriculum in the U.S. at the University of California in 1913, helped found the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Musicological_Society&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Musicological Society (page does not exist)">American Musicological Society</a>, and was a key founder of the academic discipline of <a href="/wiki/Ethnomusicology" title="Ethnomusicology">ethnomusicology</a>. Pete's mother, Constance de Clyver (née Edson), raised in <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> and trained at the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Conservatory_of_Music" title="Paris Conservatory of Music" class="mw-redirect">Paris Conservatory of Music</a>, was a concert violinist and later a teacher at the <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">Juilliard School</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-d20_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d20-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1912, Charles Seeger was hired to establish the music department at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley" title="University of California, Berkeley">University of California, Berkeley</a>, but was forced to resign in 1918 because of his outspoken <a href="/wiki/Pacifism" title="Pacifism">pacifism</a> during <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Charles and Constance moved back east, making Charles' parents' estate in <a href="/wiki/Patterson,_New_York" title="Patterson, New York">Patterson, New York</a>, northeast of New York City, their base of operations. When baby Pete was eighteen months old, they set out with him and his two older brothers in a homemade trailer, on a quixotic mission to bring musical uplift to the working people in the American South.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Upon their return, Constance taught <a href="/wiki/Violin" title="Violin">violin</a> and Charles taught composition at the New York <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Musical_Art" title="Institute of Musical Art" class="mw-redirect">Institute of Musical Art</a> (later <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">Juilliard</a>), whose president, family friend <a href="/wiki/Frank_Damrosch" title="Frank Damrosch">Frank Damrosch</a>, was Constance's adoptive "uncle". Charles also taught part-time at the <a href="/wiki/New_School_for_Social_Research" title="New School for Social Research" class="mw-redirect">New School for Social Research</a>. Career and money tensions led to quarrels and reconciliations, but when Charles discovered Constance had opened a secret bank account in her own name, they separated, and Charles took custody of their three sons.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Beginning in 1936, Charles held various administrative positions in the federal government's <a href="/wiki/Resettlement_Administration" title="Resettlement Administration">Farm Resettlement program</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Works_Projects_Administration" title="Works Projects Administration" class="mw-redirect">WPA</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Federal_Music_Project" title="Federal Music Project">Federal Music Project</a> (1938–1940), and the wartime <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pan_American_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pan American Union (page does not exist)">Pan American Union</a>. After <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, he taught <a href="/wiki/Ethnomusicology" title="Ethnomusicology">ethnomusicology</a> at the University of California and <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">Yale University</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-w4_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-w4-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>Charles and Constance divorced when Pete was seven, and in 1932 Charles married his composition student and assistant, <a href="/wiki/Ruth_Crawford_Seeger" title="Ruth Crawford Seeger">Ruth Crawford Seeger</a>, now considered by many to be one of the most important <a href="/wiki/Modernism_(music)" title="Modernism (music)">modernist</a> <a href="/wiki/Composer" title="Composer">composers</a> of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> Deeply interested in folk music, Ruth had contributed musical arrangements to <a href="/wiki/Carl_Sandburg" title="Carl Sandburg">Carl Sandburg</a>'s extremely influential folk song anthology <a href="/wiki/Carl_Sandburg#Folk_music" title="Carl Sandburg">the <i>American Songbag</i></a> (1927) and later created significant original settings for eight of Sandburg's poems.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> Pete's eldest brother, Charles Seeger III, was a radio astronomer, and his next older brother, John Seeger, taught in the 1950s at the <a href="/wiki/Dalton_School" title="Dalton School">Dalton School</a> in Manhattan and was the principal from 1960 to 1976 at <a href="/wiki/Ethical_Culture_Fieldston_School" title="Ethical Culture Fieldston School">Fieldston Lower School</a> in <a href="/wiki/The_Bronx" title="The Bronx">the Bronx</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Pete's uncle, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alan_Seeger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alan Seeger (page does not exist)">Alan Seeger</a>, a noted poet ("I Have a Rendezvous with Death"), had been one of the first American soldiers to be killed in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>. All four of Pete's half siblings from his father's second marriage – Margaret (Peggy), Mike, Barbara, and Penelope (Penny) – became folk singers. <a href="/wiki/Peggy_Seeger" title="Peggy Seeger">Peggy Seeger</a>, a well-known performer in her own right, was married for many years to British folk singer and activist <a href="/wiki/Ewan_MacColl" title="Ewan MacColl">Ewan MacColl</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mike_Seeger" title="Mike Seeger">Mike Seeger</a> was a founder of the <a href="/wiki/New_Lost_City_Ramblers" title="New Lost City Ramblers">New Lost City Ramblers</a>, one of whose members, <a href="/wiki/John_Cohen_(musician)" title="John Cohen (musician)">John Cohen</a>, married Pete's half-sister Penny — also a talented singer who died young. Barbara Seeger joined her siblings in recording folk songs for children. In 1935, Pete attended Camp Rising Sun, an international leadership camp held every summer in upstate New York that influenced his life's work. He visited most recently in 2012.
</p><p>In 1943, Pete married <a href="/w/index.php?title=Toshi_Seeger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Toshi Seeger (page does not exist)">Toshi-Aline Ōta</a>, whom he credited with being the support that helped make the rest of his life possible. The couple remained married until Toshi's death in July 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-wife_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wife-14">[14]</a></sup> Their first child, Peter Ōta Seeger, was born in 1944 and died at six months, while Pete was deployed overseas. Pete never saw him.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> They went on to have three more children: Daniel (an accomplished photographer and filmmaker), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mika_Seeger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mika Seeger (page does not exist)">Mika</a> (a potter and muralist), and Tinya (a potter), as well as grandchildren <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tao_Rodr%C3%ADguez-Seeger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tao Rodríguez-Seeger (page does not exist)">Tao</a> (a musician), Cassie (an artist), Kitama Cahill-Jackson (a filmmaker), Moraya (a graduate student married to the NFL player <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chris_DeGeare&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chris DeGeare (page does not exist)">Chris DeGeare</a>), Penny, and Isabelle. Tao is a folk musician in his own right, who sings and plays guitar, banjo, and harmonica with <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Mammals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Mammals (page does not exist)">the Mammals</a>. Kitama Jackson is a <a href="/wiki/Documentary_film" title="Documentary film">documentary filmmaker</a> who was associate producer of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=PBS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PBS (page does not exist)">PBS</a> documentary <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pete_Seeger:_The_Power_of_Song&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (page does not exist)">Pete Seeger: The Power of Song</a></i>.
</p><p>When asked about his religious or spiritual views, Seeger replied: "I feel most spiritual when I’m out in the woods. I feel part of <a href="/wiki/Pantheism" title="Pantheism">nature</a>. Or looking up at the stars. [I used to say] I was an atheist. Now I say, it’s all according to your definition of God. According to my definition of God, I’m not an atheist. Because I think God is everything. Whenever I open my eyes I’m looking at God. Whenever I’m listening to something I’m listening to God.".<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> He was a member of a <a href="/wiki/Unitarian_Universalism" title="Unitarian Universalism">Unitarian Universalist Church</a> in New York.<sup id="cite_ref-UU_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UU-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>Seeger lived in <a href="/wiki/Beacon,_New_York" title="Beacon, New York">Beacon, New York</a>. He remained engaged politically and maintained an active lifestyle in the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Valley" title="Hudson Valley">Hudson Valley</a> region of New York throughout his life. He and Toshi purchased their land in 1949 and lived there first in a trailer, then in a log cabin they built themselves. Toshi died in Beacon on July 9, 2013<sup id="cite_ref-wife_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wife-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> and Pete died in New York City on January 27, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTdeath_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTdeath-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career_as_a_musician_and_activist">Career as a musician and activist</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_work">Early work</span></h3>
At four, Seeger was sent away to <a href="/wiki/Boarding_school" title="Boarding school">boarding school</a>, but came home two years later, when his parents learned the school had failed to inform them he had contracted <a href="/wiki/Scarlet_fever" title="Scarlet fever">scarlet fever</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> He attended first and second grades in <a href="/wiki/Nyack,_New_York" title="Nyack, New York">Nyack, New York</a>, where his mother lived, before entering boarding school in <a href="/wiki/Ridgefield,_Connecticut" title="Ridgefield, Connecticut">Ridgefield, Connecticut</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> Despite being classical musicians, his parents did not press him to play an instrument. On his own, the otherwise bookish and withdrawn boy gravitated to the <a href="/wiki/Ukulele" title="Ukulele">ukulele</a>, becoming adept at entertaining his classmates with it, while laying the basis for his subsequent remarkable audience rapport. At thirteen, Seeger enrolled in the Avon Old Farms prep school in <a href="/wiki/Avon,_Connecticut" title="Avon, Connecticut">Avon, Connecticut</a> from which he graduated in 1936. He was selected to attend <a href="/w/index.php?title=Camp_Rising_Sun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Camp Rising Sun (page does not exist)">Camp Rising Sun</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_E._Jonas_Foundation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George E. Jonas Foundation (page does not exist)">George E. Jonas Foundation</a>'s international summer leadership program. During the summer of 1936, while traveling with his father and stepmother, Pete heard the five-string <a href="/wiki/Banjo" title="Banjo">banjo</a> for the first time at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bascom_Lamar_Lunsford&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bascom Lamar Lunsford (page does not exist)">Mountain Dance and Folk Festival</a> in western <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina" title="North Carolina">North Carolina</a> near <a href="/wiki/Asheville,_North_Carolina" title="Asheville, North Carolina">Asheville</a>, organized by local <a href="/wiki/Folkloristics" title="Folkloristics">folklorist</a>, lecturer, and traditional music performer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bascom_Lamar_Lunsford&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bascom Lamar Lunsford (page does not exist)">Bascom Lamar Lunsford</a>, whom Charles Seeger had hired for <a href="/wiki/Resettlement_Administration" title="Resettlement Administration">Farm Resettlement</a> music projects.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> The festival took place in a covered baseball field. There the Seegers<blockquote>watched square-dance teams from Bear Wallow, Happy Hollow, Cane Creek, Spooks Branch, Cheoah Valley, Bull Creek, and Soco Gap; heard the five-string banjo player <a href="/w/index.php?title=Samantha_Bumgarner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Samantha Bumgarner (page does not exist)">Samantha Bumgarner</a>; and family string bands, including a group of Indians from the Cherokee reservation who played string instruments and sang ballads. They wandered among the crowds who camped out at the edge of the field, hearing music being made there as well. As Lunsford’s daughter would later recall, those country people "held the riches that Dad had discovered. They could sing, fiddle, pick the banjos, and guitars with traditional grace and style found nowhere else but deep in the mountains. I can still hear those haunting melodies drift over the ball park."<sup id="cite_ref-Judith_Tick_p._239_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Judith_Tick_p._239-23">[23]</a></sup></blockquote> For the Seegers, experiencing the beauty of this music firsthand was a "conversion experience". Pete was deeply affected and, after learning basic strokes from Lunsford, spent much of the next four years trying to master the five-string banjo.<sup id="cite_ref-Judith_Tick_p._239_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Judith_Tick_p._239-23">[23]</a></sup> The teenage Seeger also sometimes accompanied his parents to regular Saturday evening gatherings at the <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a> loft of painter and art teacher <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Hart_Benton_(painter)" title="Thomas Hart Benton (painter)">Thomas Hart Benton</a> and his wife Rita. Benton, a lover of Americana, played <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cindy_(folk_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cindy (folk song) (page does not exist)">"Cindy"</a> and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Joe_Clark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Joe Clark (page does not exist)">Old Joe Clark</a>" with his students <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Pollock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Pollock (page does not exist)">Charlie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Pollock" title="Jackson Pollock">Jackson Pollock</a>; friends from the <a href="/wiki/Old-time_music" title="Old-time music">"hillbilly"</a> recording industry; as well as <a href="/wiki/Avant-garde_music" title="Avant-garde music">avant-garde</a> composers <a href="/wiki/Carl_Ruggles" title="Carl Ruggles">Carl Ruggles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Cowell" title="Henry Cowell">Henry Cowell</a>. It was at one of Benton's parties that Pete heard "<a href="/wiki/John_Henry_(folklore)#Music" title="John Henry (folklore)">John Henry</a>" for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
Seeger enrolled at <a href="/wiki/Harvard_College" title="Harvard College">Harvard College</a> on a partial scholarship, but as he became increasingly involved with politics and folk music, his grades suffered and he lost his scholarship. He dropped out of college in 1938.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> He dreamed of a career in journalism and took courses in art, as well. His first musical gig was leading students in folk singing at the <a href="/wiki/Dalton_School" title="Dalton School">Dalton School</a>, where his aunt was principal. He polished his performance skills during a summer stint of touring New York State with The Vagabond Puppeteers (Jerry Oberwager, 22; Mary Wallace, 22; and Harriet Holtzman, 23), a traveling <a href="/wiki/Puppet_theater" title="Puppet theater" class="mw-redirect">puppet theater</a> "inspired by rural education campaigns of post-revolutionary Mexico".<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> One of their shows coincided with a strike by dairy farmers. The group reprised its act in October in New York City. An article in the October 2, 1939, <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Worker" title="Daily Worker">Daily Worker</a></i> reported on the Puppeteers' six-week tour this way:<blockquote>During the entire trip the group never ate once in a restaurant. They slept out at night under the stars and cooked their own meals in the open, very often they were the guests of farmers. At rural affairs and union meetings, the farm women would bring "suppers" and would vie with each other to see who could feed the troupe most, and after the affair the farmers would have earnest discussions about who would have the honor of taking them home for the night.</blockquote><blockquote>"They fed us too well," the girls reported. "And we could live the entire winter just by taking advantage of all the offers to spend a week on the farm."</blockquote><blockquote>In the farmers' homes they talked about politics and the farmers’ problems, about <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism" title="Antisemitism">antisemitism</a> and Unionism, about war and peace and social security—"and always," the puppeteers report, "the farmers wanted to know what can be done to create a stronger unity between themselves and city workers. They felt the need of this more strongly than ever before, and the support of the CIO in their milk strike has given them a new understanding and a new respect for the power that lies in solidarity. One summer has convinced us that a minimum of organized effort on the part of city organizations—unions, consumers’ bodies, the American Labor Party and similar groups—can not only reach the farmers but weld them into a pretty solid front with city folks that will be one of the best guarantees for progress.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup></blockquote> That fall Seeger took a job in <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, assisting <a href="/wiki/Alan_Lomax" title="Alan Lomax">Alan Lomax</a>, a friend of his father's, at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Archive_of_American_Folk_Song&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Archive of American Folk Song (page does not exist)">Archive of American Folk Song</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Library_of_Congress&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Library of Congress (page does not exist)">Library of Congress</a>. Seeger's job was to help Lomax sift through commercial "<a href="/w/index.php?title=African_American_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African American music (page does not exist)">race</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Old-time_music" title="Old-time music">hillbilly</a>" music and select recordings that best represented American folk music, a project funded by the music division of the Pan American Union (later the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>), of whose music division his father, Charles Seeger, was head (1938–53).<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Lomax also encouraged Seeger's folk singing vocation, and Seeger was soon appearing as a regular performer on Alan Lomax and <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Ray" title="Nicholas Ray">Nicholas Ray</a>'s weekly <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">Columbia Broadcasting</a> show <i>Back Where I Come From</i> (1940–41) alongside of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Josh_White&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Josh White (page does not exist)">Josh White</a>, <a href="/wiki/Burl_Ives" title="Burl Ives">Burl Ives</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lead_Belly" title="Lead Belly">Lead Belly</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Woody_Guthrie" title="Woody Guthrie">Woody Guthrie</a> (whom he had first met at <a href="/wiki/Will_Geer" title="Will Geer">Will Geer</a>'s Grapes of Wrath benefit concert for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Migrant_workers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Migrant workers (page does not exist)">migrant workers</a> on March 3, 1940). <i>Back Where I Come From</i> was unique in having a <a href="/wiki/Racial_integration" title="Racial integration">racially integrated</a> cast, which made news when it performed in March 1941 at a command performance at the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a> organized by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eleanor_Roosevelt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eleanor Roosevelt (page does not exist)">Eleanor Roosevelt</a> called "An Evening of Songs for American Soldiers,"<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> before an audience that included the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Secretary_of_War" title="U.S. Secretary of War" class="mw-redirect">Secretaries of War</a>, <a href="/wiki/U.S._Secretary_of_the_Treasury" title="U.S. Secretary of the Treasury" class="mw-redirect">Treasury</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Secretary_of_the_Navy" title="U.S. Secretary of the Navy" class="mw-redirect">Navy</a>, among other notables. The show was a success but was not picked up by commercial sponsors for nationwide broadcasting because of its integrated cast. During <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">the war</a>, Seeger also performed on nationwide radio broadcasts by <a href="/wiki/Norman_Corwin" title="Norman Corwin">Norman Corwin</a>.
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PeteSeeger2.jpg" title="File:PeteSeeger2.jpg">File:PeteSeeger2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Pete Seeger entertaining <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eleanor_Roosevelt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eleanor Roosevelt (page does not exist)">Eleanor Roosevelt</a> (center), honored guest at a racially integrated Valentine's Day party marking the opening of a Canteen of the United Federal Labor, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Congress_of_Industrial_Organizations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Congress of Industrial Organizations (page does not exist)">CIO</a>, in then-segregated Washington, D.C. Photographed by Joseph Horne for the Office of War Information, 1944.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In 1949, Seeger worked as the vocal instructor for the progressive <a href="/w/index.php?title=City_and_Country_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="City and Country School (page does not exist)">City and Country School</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>, New York.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_activism">Early activism</span></h3>
<p>In 1936, at the age of 17, Pete Seeger joined the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Young_Communist_League,_USA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Young Communist League, USA (page does not exist)">Young Communist League</a> (YCL), then at the height of its popularity and influence. In 1942 he became a member of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_USA" title="Communist Party USA">Communist Party USA</a> (CPUSA) itself. He eventually "drifted away" (his words) from the Party in the late 1940s and 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the spring of 1941, the twenty-one-year-old Seeger performed as a member of the <a href="/wiki/Almanac_Singers" title="Almanac Singers">Almanac Singers</a> along with Millard Lampell, <a href="/wiki/Cisco_Houston" title="Cisco Houston">Cisco Houston</a>, Woody Guthrie, Butch and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bess_Lomax_Hawes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bess Lomax Hawes (page does not exist)">Bess Lomax Hawes</a>, and Lee Hays. Seeger and the Almanacs cut several albums of 78s on Keynote and other labels, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Songs_for_John_Doe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Songs for John Doe (page does not exist)">Songs for John Doe</a></i> (recorded in late February or March and released in May 1941), the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Talking_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Talking Union (page does not exist)">Talking Union</a></i>, and an album each of sea chanteys and pioneer songs. Written by Millard Lampell, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Songs_for_John_Doe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Songs for John Doe (page does not exist)">Songs for John Doe</a></i> was performed by Lampell, Seeger, and Hays, joined by Josh White and Sam Gary. It contained lines such as, "It wouldn't be much thrill to die for Du Pont in Brazil," that were sharply critical of <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Roosevelt</a>'s unprecedented peacetime draft (enacted in September 1940). This anti-war/anti-draft tone reflected the Communist Party line after the 1939 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Molotov-Ribbentrop_Pact&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact (page does not exist)">Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact</a>, which maintained the war was "phony" and a mere pretext for big American corporations to get Hitler to attack Soviet Russia. Seeger has said he believed this line of argument at the time—as did many fellow members of the Young Communist League (YCL). Though nominally members of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Popular_Front&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Popular Front (page does not exist)">Popular Front</a>, which was allied with Roosevelt and more moderate liberals, the YCL's members still smarted from Roosevelt and <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Churchill</a>'s arms embargo to Loyalist Spain (which Roosevelt later called a mistake),<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> and the alliance frayed in the confusing welter of events.
</p><p>A June 16, 1941, review in <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine, which under its owner, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Luce" title="Henry Luce">Henry Luce</a>, had become very interventionist, denounced the Almanacs' <i>John Doe</i>, accusing it of scrupulously echoing what it called "the mendacious Moscow tune" that "Franklin Roosevelt is leading an unwilling people into a J. P. Morgan war." Eleanor Roosevelt, a fan of folk music, reportedly found the album "in bad taste," though President Roosevelt, when the album was shown to him, merely observed, correctly as it turned out, that few people would ever hear it. More alarmist was the reaction of eminent German-born Harvard Professor of Government <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carl_Joachim_Friedrich&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carl Joachim Friedrich (page does not exist)">Carl Joachim Friedrich</a>, an adviser on domestic propaganda to the United States military. In a review in the June 1941 <i><a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Monthly" title="Atlantic Monthly" class="mw-redirect">Atlantic Monthly</a></i>, entitled "The Poison in Our System," he pronounced <i>Songs for John Doe</i> "...strictly subversive and illegal," "...whether Communist or Nazi financed," and "a matter for the attorney general," observing further that "mere" legal "suppression" would not be sufficient to counteract this type of populist poison,<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> the poison being folk music, and the ease with which it could be spread.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>At that point, the U.S. had not yet entered the war but was energetically re-arming. <a href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">African Americans</a> were barred from working in defense plants, a situation that greatly angered both African Americans and white progressives. Civil rights leader <a href="/wiki/A._J._Muste" title="A. J. Muste">A. J. Muste</a> and Black union leaders <a href="/wiki/A._Philip_Randolph" title="A. Philip Randolph">A. Philip Randolph</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bayard_Rustin" title="Bayard Rustin">Bayard Rustin</a> began planning a huge march on Washington to protest racial discrimination in war industries and to urge desegregation of the armed forces. The march, which many regard as the first manifestation of the Civil Rights Movement, was canceled after President Roosevelt issued <a href="/wiki/Executive_Order_8802" title="Executive Order 8802">Executive Order 8802</a> (The Fair Employment Act) of June 25, 1941, barring discrimination in hiring by companies holding federal contracts for defense work. This Presidential act defused black anger considerably, although the United States Army still refused to desegregate, declining to participate in what it called "<a href="/wiki/Social_engineering_(political_science)" title="Social engineering (political science)">social engineering</a>."{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>Roosevelt's order came three days after Hitler broke the non-aggression pact and invaded the Soviet Union, at which time the Communist Party quickly directed its members to get behind the draft and forbade participation in strikes for the duration of the war (angering some leftists). Copies of <i>Songs for John Doe</i> were removed from sale, and the remaining inventory destroyed, though a few copies may exist in the hands of private collectors.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> The Almanac Singers' <i>Talking Union</i> album, on the other hand, was reissued as an LP by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Folkways_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Folkways Records (page does not exist)">Folkways</a> (FH 5285A) in 1955 and is still available. The following year the Almanacs issued <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dear_Mr._President_(Almanac_Singers_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dear Mr. President (Almanac Singers album) (page does not exist)">Dear Mr. President</a></i>, an album in support of Roosevelt and the war effort. The title song, "Dear Mr. President," was a solo by Pete Seeger, and its lines expressed his lifelong credo:
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Now, Mr. President, / We haven't always agreed in the past, I know, / But that ain't at all important now. / What is important is what we got to do, / We got to lick Mr. Hitler, and until we do, / Other things can wait.//
</p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p>Now, as I think of our great land . . . / I know it ain't perfect, but it will be someday, / Just give us a little time. // This is the reason that I want to fight, / Not 'cause everything's perfect, or everything's right. / No, it's just the opposite: I'm fightin' because / I want a better America, and better laws, / And better homes, and jobs, and schools, / And no more Jim Crow, and no more rules like / "You can't ride on this train 'cause you're a Negro," / "You can't live here 'cause you're a Jew,"/ "You can't work here 'cause you're a union man."//
</p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p>So, Mr. President, / We got this one big job to do / That's lick Mr. Hitler and when we're through, / Let no one else ever take his place / To trample down the human race. / So what I want is you to give me a gun / So we can hurry up and get the job done.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Seeger's critics, however, have continued to bring up the Almanacs' repudiated <i>Songs for John Doe</i>. In 1942, a year after the <i>John Doe</i> album's brief appearance (and disappearance), the FBI decided that the now-pro-war Almanacs were still endangering the war effort by subverting recruitment. According to the New York <i>World Telegram</i> (February 14, 1942), Carl Friedrich's 1941 article "The Poison in Our System" was printed up as a pamphlet and distributed by the Council for Democracy (an organization that Friedrich and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Luce" title="Henry Luce">Henry Luce</a>'s right hand man, <a href="/w/index.php?title=C._D._Jackson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="C. D. Jackson (page does not exist)">C. D. Jackson</a>, Vice President of <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine, had founded "...to combat all the nazi, fascist, communist, pacifist..." antiwar groups in the United States).<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> and was shown to the Almanac's employers in order to keep them off the air. Coincidentally, defamatory reviews and gossip items appeared in New York newspapers whenever they performed in public, and ultimately the Almanacs had to disband.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>His critics have also tried to downplay the sincerity of Seeger's “anti-war” sentiments, and even to suggest that he was a supporter of Nazi Germany, by asserting that Seeger was only anti-war in the early 1940s because at the time the Soviet Union had a non-aggression pact with Nazi Germany, and that he immediately became pro-war after the USSR was invaded.  They support this assertion by pointing out, incorrectly, that the Weavers' album Dear Mr. President (supporting the war effort) was released “shortly” after Germany invaded the Soviet Union in June 1941.  However, Dear Mr. President was actually released a year later, in June 1942, six months after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and the United States’ entry into the war.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Seeger served in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">U.S. Army</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pacific_Ocean_theater_of_World_War_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pacific Ocean theater of World War II (page does not exist)">Pacific</a>. He was trained as an airplane mechanic, but was reassigned to entertain the American troops with music. Later, when people asked him what he did in the war, he always answered "I strummed my banjo." After returning from service, Seeger and others established <a href="/w/index.php?title=People%27s_Songs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="People's Songs (page does not exist)">People's Songs</a>, conceived as a nationwide organization with branches on both coasts and designed to "Create, promote and distribute songs of labor and the American People"<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> With Pete Seeger as its director, People's Songs worked for the 1948 presidential campaign of Roosevelt's former Secretary of Agriculture and Vice President, <a href="/wiki/Henry_A._Wallace" title="Henry A. Wallace">Henry A. Wallace</a>, who ran as a third-party candidate on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Progressive_Party_(United_States,_1948)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Progressive Party (United States, 1948) (page does not exist)">Progressive Party</a> ticket. Despite having attracted enormous crowds nationwide, however, Wallace won only in New York City, and, in the red-baiting frenzy that followed, he was excoriated (as Roosevelt had not been) for accepting the help in his campaign of Communists and fellow travelers such as Seeger and singer <a href="/wiki/Paul_Robeson" title="Paul Robeson">Paul Robeson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spanish_Civil_War_songs">Spanish Civil War songs</span></h3>
<p>Seeger had been a fervent supporter of the Republican forces in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spanish Civil War (page does not exist)">Spanish Civil War</a>. In 1943, with <a href="/wiki/Tom_Glazer" title="Tom Glazer">Tom Glazer</a> and Bess and Baldwin Hawes, he recorded an album of 78s called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Songs_of_the_Lincoln_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Songs of the Lincoln Battalion (page does not exist)">Songs of the Lincoln Battalion</a></i> on Moe Asch's Stinson label. This included such songs as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=There%27s_a_Valley_in_Spain_called_Jarama&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="There's a Valley in Spain called Jarama (page does not exist)">There's a Valley in Spain called Jarama</a>," and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ay_Carmela&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ay Carmela (page does not exist)">Viva la Quince Brigada</a>." In 1960, this collection was re-issued by Moe Asch as one side of a Folkways LP called <i>Songs of the Lincoln and International Brigades</i>. On the other side was a reissue of the legendary <i>Six Songs for Democracy</i> (originally recorded in Barcelona in 1938 while bombs were falling), performed by <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Busch_(actor)" title="Ernst Busch (actor)">Ernst Busch</a> and a chorus of members of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Th%C3%A4lmann_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thälmann Battalion (page does not exist)">Thälmann Battalion</a>, made up of refugees from Nazi Germany. The songs were: "Moorsoldaten" (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Peat_Bog_Soldiers_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peat Bog Soldiers (song) (page does not exist)">"Peat Bog Soldiers"</a>, composed by political prisoners of German concentration camps), "Die Thaelmann-Kolonne," "Hans Beimler," "Das Lied Von Der Einheitsfront" ("Song of The United Front" by <a href="/wiki/Hanns_Eisler" title="Hanns Eisler">Hanns Eisler</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bertolt_Brecht&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bertolt Brecht (page does not exist)">Bertolt Brecht</a>), "Der Internationalen Brigaden" ("Song Of The International Brigades"), and "Los cuatro generales" ("The Four Generals," known in English as "The Four Insurgent Generals").
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Group_recordings">Group recordings</span></h3>
<p>As a self-described "split tenor" (between an alto and a tenor),<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> Pete Seeger was a founding member of two highly influential folk groups: The <a href="/wiki/Almanac_Singers" title="Almanac Singers">Almanac Singers</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Weavers" title="The Weavers">the Weavers</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Almanac_Singers" title="Almanac Singers">Almanac Singers</a>, which Seeger co-founded in 1941 with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Millard_Lampell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Millard Lampell (page does not exist)">Millard Lampell</a> and Arkansas singer and activist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lee_Hays&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lee Hays (page does not exist)">Lee Hays</a>, was a topical group, designed to function as a singing newspaper promoting the industrial unionization movement,<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> racial and religious inclusion, and other progressive causes. Its personnel included, at various times: <a href="/wiki/Woody_Guthrie" title="Woody Guthrie">Woody Guthrie</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bess_Lomax_Hawes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bess Lomax Hawes (page does not exist)">Bess Lomax Hawes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sis_Cunningham" title="Sis Cunningham">Sis Cunningham</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Josh_White&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Josh White (page does not exist)">Josh White</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sam_Gary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sam Gary (page does not exist)">Sam Gary</a>. As a controversial Almanac singer, the 21-year-old Seeger performed under the stage name "Pete Bowers" to avoid compromising his father's government career.
</p><p>In 1950, the Almanacs were reconstituted as <a href="/wiki/The_Weavers" title="The Weavers">the Weavers</a>, named after the title of an 1892 play by <a href="/wiki/Gerhart_Hauptmann" title="Gerhart Hauptmann">Gerhart Hauptmann</a> about a workers' strike (which contained the lines, "We'll stand it no more, come what may!"). Besides Pete Seeger (performing under his own name), members of the Weavers included charter Almanac member Lee Hays, <a href="/wiki/Ronnie_Gilbert" title="Ronnie Gilbert">Ronnie Gilbert</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fred_Hellerman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fred Hellerman (page does not exist)">Fred Hellerman</a>; later <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Hamilton_(musician)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Hamilton (musician) (page does not exist)">Frank Hamilton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Erik_Darling" title="Erik Darling">Erik Darling</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bernie_Krause&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bernie Krause (page does not exist)">Bernie Krause</a> serially took Seeger's place. In the atmosphere of the 1950s red scare, the Weavers' repertoire had to be less overtly topical than that of the Almanacs had been, and its progressive message was couched in indirect language—arguably rendering it even more powerful. The Weavers on occasion performed in tuxedos (unlike the Almanacs, who had dressed informally) and their managers refused to let them perform at political venues. The Weavers' string of major <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chart-topper&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chart-topper (page does not exist)">hits</a> began with "<a href="/w/index.php?title=On_Top_of_Old_Smoky&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="On Top of Old Smoky (page does not exist)">On Top of Old Smoky</a>" and an arrangement of <a href="/wiki/Lead_Belly" title="Lead Belly">Lead Belly</a>'s signature waltz, "<a href="/wiki/Goodnight,_Irene" title="Goodnight, Irene">Goodnight, Irene</a>,"<sup id="cite_ref-pc1_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc1-4">[4]</a></sup> which topped the charts for 13 weeks in 1950<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> and was covered by many other pop singers. On the flip side of "Irene" was the Israeli song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Tzena,_Tzena,_Tzena&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tzena, Tzena, Tzena (page does not exist)">Tzena, Tzena, Tzena</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-pc1_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc1-4">[4]</a></sup> Other Weaver hits included <a href="/w/index.php?title=Woody_Guthrie_discography&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Woody Guthrie discography (page does not exist)">"Dusty Old Dust" ("So Long It's Been Good to Know You" by Woody Guthrie)</a>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Kisses_Sweeter_than_Wine_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kisses Sweeter than Wine (song) (page does not exist)">Kisses Sweeter Than Wine</a>" (by Hays, Seeger, and Lead Belly) and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Africa (page does not exist)">South African</a> Zulu song by Solomon Linda, "<a href="/wiki/Wimoweh" title="Wimoweh" class="mw-redirect">Wimoweh</a>" (about <a href="/wiki/Shaka" title="Shaka">Shaka</a>), among others.
</p><p>The Weavers' performing career was abruptly derailed in 1953 at the peak of their popularity when blacklisting prompted radio stations to refuse to play their records and all their bookings were canceled. They briefly returned to the stage, however, at a sold-out reunion at Carnegie Hall in 1955 and in a subsequent <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reunion_tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reunion tour (page does not exist)">reunion tour</a>, which produced a hit version of <a href="/wiki/Merle_Travis" title="Merle Travis">Merle Travis</a>'s "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sixteen_Tons&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sixteen Tons (page does not exist)">Sixteen Tons</a>" as well as LPs of their concert performances. "<a href="/wiki/Kumbaya" title="Kumbaya">Kumbaya</a>," a <a href="/wiki/Gullah" title="Gullah">Gullah</a> black spiritual dating from slavery days, was also introduced to wide audiences by Pete Seeger and the Weavers (in 1959), becoming a staple of Boy and Girl Scout campfires.
</p><p>In the late 1950s, <a href="/wiki/The_Kingston_Trio" title="The Kingston Trio">the Kingston Trio</a> was formed in direct imitation of (and homage to) the Weavers, covering much of the latter's repertoire, though with a more buttoned-down, uncontroversial, and mainstream collegiate persona. The Kingston Trio produced another phenomenal succession of Billboard chart hits and in its turn spawned a legion of imitators, laying the groundwork for the 1960s commercial folk revival.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Documentary_film" title="Documentary film">documentary film</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pete_Seeger:_The_Power_of_Song&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (page does not exist)">Pete Seeger: The Power of Song</a></i> (2007), Seeger states that he resigned from the Weavers when the three other band members agreed to perform a <a href="/wiki/Jingle" title="Jingle">jingle</a> for a <a href="/wiki/Tobacco_advertising" title="Tobacco advertising">cigarette commercial</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Banjo_and_12-string_guitar">Banjo and 12-string guitar</span></h3>
<p>In 1948, Seeger wrote the first version of his now-classic <i>How to Play the Five-String Banjo</i>, a book that many <a href="/wiki/Banjo" title="Banjo">banjo</a> players credit with starting them off on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Musical_instrument&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Musical instrument (page does not exist)">instrument</a>. He went on to invent the <i>Long Neck</i> or <i>Seeger</i> banjo. This instrument is three frets longer than a typical banjo, is slightly longer than a <a href="/wiki/Bass_guitar" title="Bass guitar">bass guitar</a> at 25 frets, and is tuned a minor third lower than the normal 5-string banjo. Hitherto strictly limited to the Appalachian region, the five-string banjo became known nationwide as the American folk instrument par excellence, largely thanks to Seeger's championing of and improvements to it. According to an unnamed musician quoted in <a href="/w/index.php?title=David_King_Dunaway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="David King Dunaway (page does not exist)">David King Dunaway</a>'s biography, "by nesting a resonant chord between two precise notes, a melody note and a chiming note on the fifth string", Pete Seeger "gentrified" the more percussive traditional <a href="/wiki/Appalachia" title="Appalachia">Appalachian</a> "frailing" style, "with its vigorous hammering of the forearm and its percussive rapping of the fingernail on the banjo head."<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> Although what Dunaway's informant describes is the age-old droned frailing style, the implication is that Seeger made this more acceptable to mass audiences by omitting some of its percussive complexities, while presumably still preserving the characteristic driving rhythmic quality associated with the style.
</p><p>From the late 1950s on, Seeger also accompanied himself on the <a href="/wiki/12-string_guitar" title="12-string guitar" class="mw-redirect">12-string guitar</a>, an instrument of Mexican origin that had been associated with <a href="/wiki/Lead_Belly" title="Lead Belly">Lead Belly</a>, who had styled himself "the King of the 12-String Guitar". Seeger's distinctive custom-made guitars had a triangular soundhole. He combined the long scale length (approximately 28") and <a href="/wiki/Capo" title="Capo">capo-to-key</a> techniques that he favored on the banjo with a variant of <a href="/wiki/Drop_D_tuning" title="Drop D tuning">drop-D (DADGBE) tuning</a>, tuned two whole steps down with very heavy strings, which he played with thumb and finger picks.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Introduction_of_the_.22Steel_Pan.22_to_U.S._audiences">Introduction of the "Steel Pan" to U.S. audiences</span></h3>
<p>In 1956, then "Peter" Seeger (see film credits) and his wife, Toshi, traveled to Port of Spain, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trinidad_and_Tobago&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trinidad and Tobago (page does not exist)">Trinidad</a>, to seek out information on the <a href="/wiki/Steelpan" title="Steelpan">steelpan</a>, steel drum or "Ping-Pong" as it was sometimes called. The two searched out a local panyard director Isaiah, and proceeded to film the construction, tuning and playing of the then new, national instrument of Trinidad-Tobago. He was attempting to include the unique flavor of the steel pan into America Folk music.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_McCarthy_era">The McCarthy era</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pete_Seeger_NYWTS.jpg" title="File:Pete Seeger NYWTS.jpg">File:Pete Seeger NYWTS.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Pete Seeger in 1955</div></div></div>In the 1950s and, indeed, consistently throughout his life, Seeger continued his support of civil and labor rights, racial equality, international understanding, and anti-militarism (all of which had characterized the Wallace campaign) and he continued to believe that songs could help people achieve these goals. With the ever-growing revelations of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>'s atrocities and the Hungarian Revolution of 1956, however, he became increasingly disillusioned with Soviet Communism. In his PBS biography, Seeger said he "drifted away" from the CPUSA beginning in 1949 but remained friends with some who did not leave it, though he argued with them about it.<sup id="cite_ref-powersong_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-powersong-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
<p>On August 18, 1955, Seeger was subpoenaed to testify before the <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_Un-American_Activities_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House Un-American Activities Committee (page does not exist)">House Un-American Activities Committee</a> (HUAC). Alone among the many witnesses after the 1950 conviction and imprisonment of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Ten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hollywood Ten (page does not exist)">Hollywood Ten</a> for contempt of Congress, Seeger refused to plead the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fifth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution (page does not exist)">Fifth Amendment</a> (which would have asserted that his testimony might be self incriminating) and instead, as the Hollywood Ten had done, refused to name personal and political associations on the grounds that this would violate his <a href="/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="First Amendment to the United States Constitution">First Amendment</a> rights: "I am not going to answer any questions as to my association, my philosophical or religious beliefs or my political beliefs, or how I voted in any election, or any of these private affairs. I think these are very improper questions for any American to be asked, especially under such compulsion as this."<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> Seeger's refusal to answer questions that violated his fundamental Constitutional rights led to a March 26, 1957, indictment for <a href="/wiki/Contempt_of_Congress" title="Contempt of Congress">contempt of Congress</a>; for some years, he had to keep the federal government apprised of where he was going any time he left the Southern District of New York. He was convicted in a jury trial of contempt of Congress in March 1961, and sentenced to ten 1-year terms in jail (to be served simultaneously), but in May 1962 an appeals court ruled the indictment to be flawed and overturned his conviction.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1960, the <a href="/wiki/San_Diego" title="San Diego">San Diego</a> school board told him that he could not play a scheduled concert at a high school unless he signed an oath pledging that the concert would not be used to promote a communist agenda or an overthrow of the government. Seeger refused, and the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_Liberties_Union" title="American Civil Liberties Union">American Civil Liberties Union</a> obtained an <a href="/wiki/Injunction" title="Injunction">injunction</a> against the school district, allowing the concert to go on as scheduled. Almost 50 years later, in February 2009, the San Diego School District officially extended an apology to Seeger for the actions of their predecessors.<sup id="cite_ref-SignOnSD_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SignOnSD-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Folk_music_revival">Folk music revival</span></h3>
<p>To earn money during the blacklist period of the late 1950s and early 1960s, Seeger worked gigs as a music teacher in schools and summer camps, and traveled the college campus circuit. He also recorded as many as five albums a year for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moe_Asch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moe Asch (page does not exist)">Moe Asch</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Folkways_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Folkways Records (page does not exist)">Folkways Records</a> label. As the nuclear disarmament movement picked up steam in the late 1950s and early 1960s, Seeger's anti-war songs, such as, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Where_Have_All_the_Flowers_Gone%3F&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Where Have All the Flowers Gone? (page does not exist)">Where Have All the Flowers Gone?</a>" (co-written with <a href="/wiki/Joe_Hickerson" title="Joe Hickerson">Joe Hickerson</a>), "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Turn!_Turn!_Turn!_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turn! Turn! Turn! (song) (page does not exist)">Turn! Turn! Turn!</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-pc33_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc33-54">[54]</a></sup> adapted from the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Ecclesiastes" title="Book of Ecclesiastes" class="mw-redirect">Book of Ecclesiastes</a>, and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Bells_of_Rhymney&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Bells of Rhymney (page does not exist)">The Bells of Rhymney</a>" by the Welsh poet <a href="/wiki/Idris_Davies" title="Idris Davies">Idris Davies</a><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> (1957), gained wide currency. Seeger also was closely associated with the 1960s <a href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_movement" title="Civil Rights movement" class="mw-redirect">Civil Rights movement</a> and in 1963 helped organize a landmark <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hall" title="Carnegie Hall">Carnegie Hall</a> concert, featuring the youthful <a href="/w/index.php?title=Freedom_Singers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Freedom Singers (page does not exist)">Freedom Singers</a>, as a benefit for the <a href="/wiki/Highlander_Folk_School" title="Highlander Folk School" class="mw-redirect">Highlander Folk School</a> in Tennessee. This event and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_Luther_King&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin Luther King (page does not exist)">Martin Luther King</a>'s <a href="/wiki/March_on_Washington" title="March on Washington" class="mw-redirect">March on Washington</a> in August of that year brought the Civil Rights anthem "<a href="/wiki/We_Shall_Overcome" title="We Shall Overcome">We Shall Overcome</a>" to wide audiences. A version of this song, submitted by Zilphia Horton of Highlander, had been published in Seeger's People's Songs <i>Bulletin</i> as early as in 1947.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>By this time, Seeger was a senior figure in the 1960s folk revival centered in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>, as a longtime columnist in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sing_Out!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sing Out! (page does not exist)">Sing Out!</a></i>, the successor to the People's Songs <i>Bulletin</i>, and as a founder of the topical <a href="/w/index.php?title=Broadside_Magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Broadside Magazine (page does not exist)"><i>Broadside</i></a> magazine. To describe the new crop of politically committed folk singers, he coined the phrase "Woody's children", alluding to his associate and traveling companion, <a href="/wiki/Woody_Guthrie" title="Woody Guthrie">Woody Guthrie</a>, who by this time had become a legendary figure. This urban folk-revival movement, a continuation of the activist tradition of the 1930s and 1940s and of <a href="/w/index.php?title=People%27s_Songs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="People's Songs (page does not exist)">People's Songs</a>, used adaptations of traditional tunes and lyrics to effect social change, a practice that goes back to the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Workers_of_the_World" title="Industrial Workers of the World">Industrial Workers of the World</a> or Wobblies' <i>Little Red Song Book</i>, compiled by Swedish-born union organizer <a href="/wiki/Joe_Hill" title="Joe Hill">Joe Hill</a> (1879–1915). (The <i>Little Red Song Book</i> had been a favorite of Woody Guthrie's, who was known to carry it around.){{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>Seeger toured Australia in 1963. His single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Little_Boxes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Little Boxes (page does not exist)">Little Boxes</a>", written by Malvina Reynolds, was number one in the nation's Top 40s. That tour sparked a folk boom throughout the country at a time when popular music tastes, post-<a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_JFK" title="Assassination of JFK" class="mw-redirect">Kennedy assassination</a>, competed between folk, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sur_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sur music (page does not exist)">surfing craze</a>, and the British rock boom which gave the world <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">the Beatles</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">The Rolling Stones</a>, among others. Folk clubs sprung up all over the nation, folk performers were accepted in established venues, and Australian performers singing Australian folk songs - many of their own composing - emerged in concerts and festivals, on television, and on recordings, and overseas performers were encouraged to tour Australia.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>The long television blacklist of Seeger began to end in the mid-1960s, when he hosted a regionally broadcast, educational, folk-music television show, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rainbow_Quest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rainbow Quest (page does not exist)">Rainbow Quest</a></i>. Among his guests were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johnny_Cash&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johnny Cash (page does not exist)">Johnny Cash</a>, <a href="/wiki/June_Carter" title="June Carter" class="mw-redirect">June Carter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reverend_Gary_Davis" title="Reverend Gary Davis">Reverend Gary Davis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mississippi_John_Hurt" title="Mississippi John Hurt">Mississippi John Hurt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Doc_Watson" title="Doc Watson">Doc Watson</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Stanley_Brothers" title="The Stanley Brothers">the Stanley Brothers</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_Cotten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth Cotten (page does not exist)">Elizabeth Cotten</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Patrick_Sky&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Patrick Sky (page does not exist)">Patrick Sky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buffy_Sainte-Marie" title="Buffy Sainte-Marie">Buffy Sainte-Marie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Paxton" title="Tom Paxton">Tom Paxton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judy_Collins" title="Judy Collins">Judy Collins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donovan" title="Donovan">Donovan</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Fari%C3%B1a&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richard Fariña (page does not exist)">Richard Fariña</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mimi_Fari%C3%B1a" title="Mimi Fariña">Mimi Fariña</a>, Sonny Terry and Brownie McGhee, Mamou Cajun Band, <a href="/wiki/Bernice_Johnson_Reagon" title="Bernice Johnson Reagon">Bernice Johnson Reagon</a>, The Beers Family, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roscoe_Holcomb&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roscoe Holcomb (page does not exist)">Roscoe Holcomb</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malvina_Reynolds" title="Malvina Reynolds">Malvina Reynolds</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shawn_Phillips&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shawn Phillips (page does not exist)">Shawn Phillips</a>. Thirty-nine<sup id="cite_ref-powersong_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-powersong-47">[47]</a></sup> hour-long programs were recorded at <a href="/wiki/WNJU" title="WNJU">WNJU</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark</a> studios in 1965 and 1966, produced by Seeger and his wife Toshi, with Sholom Rubinstein. The <a href="/wiki/Smothers_Brothers" title="Smothers Brothers">Smothers Brothers</a> ended Seeger's national blacklisting by broadcasting him singing "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Waist_Deep_in_the_Big_Muddy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Waist Deep in the Big Muddy (page does not exist)">Waist Deep in the Big Muddy</a>" on their CBS variety show on February 25, 1968, after his similar performance in September 1967 was censored by CBS.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 1976, Seeger wrote and recorded the anti-death penalty song "Delbert Tibbs", about the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Delbert_Tibbs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Delbert Tibbs (page does not exist)">eponymous death-row inmate</a>, who was later <a href="/w/index.php?title=Exonerated&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Exonerated (page does not exist)">exonerated</a>. Seeger wrote the music and selected the words from poems written by Tibbs.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SO!vol49_2_Pete_Seeger.PNG" title="File:SO!vol49 2 Pete Seeger.PNG">File:SO!vol49 2 Pete Seeger.PNG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Seeger at 86 on the cover of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sing_Out!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sing Out! (page does not exist)">Sing Out!</a></i> (Summer 2005), a magazine he helped found in 1950.</div></div></div>
<p>Seeger also supported the Jewish Camping Movement. He came to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Surprise_Lake_Camp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Surprise Lake Camp (page does not exist)">Surprise Lake Camp</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cold_Spring,_New_York" title="Cold Spring, New York">Cold Spring, New York</a>, over the summer many times.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> He sung and inspired countless campers.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pete_Seeger_and_Bob_Dylan">Pete Seeger and Bob Dylan</span></h4>
<p>Pete Seeger was one of the earliest backers of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Dylan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bob Dylan (page does not exist)">Bob Dylan</a> and was responsible for urging A&amp;R man <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_H._Hammond&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John H. Hammond (page does not exist)">John Hammond</a> to produce Dylan's first LP on <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Records" title="Columbia Records">Columbia</a>, and for inviting him to perform at the <a href="/wiki/Newport_Folk_Festival" title="Newport Folk Festival">Newport Folk Festival</a>, of which Seeger was a board member.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> There was a widely repeated story that Seeger was so upset over the extremely loud amplified sound that Dylan, backed by members of the <a href="/wiki/Paul_Butterfield" title="Paul Butterfield">Butterfield Blues Band</a>, brought into the 1965 <a href="/wiki/Newport_Folk_Festival" title="Newport Folk Festival">Newport Folk Festival</a> that he threatened to disconnect the equipment. There are multiple versions of what went on, some fanciful. What is certain is that tensions had been running high between Dylan's manager, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Grossman" title="Albert Grossman">Albert Grossman</a>, and Festival Board members (who besides Seeger also included <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Bikel" title="Theodore Bikel">Theodore Bikel</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bruce_Jackson_(scholar)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bruce Jackson (scholar) (page does not exist)">Bruce Jackson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Lomax" title="Alan Lomax">Alan Lomax</a>, festival MC <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Yarrow&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Yarrow (page does not exist)">Peter Yarrow</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_Wein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George Wein (page does not exist)">George Wein</a>) over the scheduling of performers and other matters. Two days earlier there had been a scuffle and brief exchange of blows between Grossman and Alan Lomax; and the Board, in an emergency session, had voted to ban Grossman from the grounds, but had backed off when George Wein pointed out that Grossman also managed highly popular draws <a href="/wiki/Odetta" title="Odetta">Odetta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peter,_Paul,_and_Mary" title="Peter, Paul, and Mary" class="mw-redirect">Peter, Paul, and Mary</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> Seeger has been portrayed as a folk "purist" who was one of the main opponents to Dylan's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Electric_Dylan_controversy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Electric Dylan controversy (page does not exist)">"going electric"</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> but when asked in 2001 about how he recalled his "objections" to the electric style, he said:
</p>
<blockquote>I couldn't understand the words. I wanted to hear the words. It was a great song, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Maggie%27s_Farm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maggie's Farm (page does not exist)">Maggie's Farm</a>," and the sound was distorted. I ran over to the guy at the controls and shouted, "Fix the sound so you can hear the words." He hollered back, "This is the way they want it." I said "Damn it, if I had an axe, I'd cut the cable right now." But I was at fault. I was the MC, and I could have said to the part of the crowd that booed Bob, "you didn't boo <a href="/wiki/Howlin%27_Wolf" title="Howlin' Wolf">Howlin' Wolf</a> yesterday. He was electric!" Though I still prefer to hear Dylan acoustic, some of his electric songs are absolutely great. Electric music is the vernacular of the second half of the twentieth century, to use my father's old term.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vietnam_War_era">Vietnam War era</span></h3>
<p>A longstanding opponent of the arms race and of the Vietnam War, Seeger <a href="/wiki/Satire" title="Satire">satirically</a> attacked then-President <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Lyndon B. Johnson">Lyndon Johnson</a> with his 1966 recording, on the album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dangerous_Songs!%3F&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dangerous Songs!? (page does not exist)">Dangerous Songs!?</a></i>, of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Len_Chandler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Len Chandler (page does not exist)">Len Chandler</a>'s children's song, <i>"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Beans_in_My_Ears&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beans in My Ears (page does not exist)">Beans in My Ears</a>"</i>. Beyond Chandler's lyrics, Seeger said that "Mrs. Jay's little son Alby" had "beans in his ears," which, as the lyrics imply,<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> ensures that a person does not hear what is said to them.
