To those opposed to continuing the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>, the phrase implied that "Alby Jay", a loose pronunciation of Johnson's nickname "LBJ," did not listen to anti-war protests as he too had "beans in his ears".
</p><p>Seeger attracted wider attention starting in 1967 with his song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Waist_Deep_in_the_Big_Muddy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Waist Deep in the Big Muddy (page does not exist)">Waist Deep in the Big Muddy</a>", about a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Captain_(land)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Captain (land) (page does not exist)">captain</a>—referred to in the lyrics as "the big fool"—who drowned while leading a platoon on maneuvers in <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a> during World War II. In the face of arguments with the management of <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a> about whether the song's political weight was in keeping with the usually light-hearted entertainment of the <i><a href="/wiki/Smothers_Brothers_Comedy_Hour" title="Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour" class="mw-redirect">Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour</a></i>, the final lines were "Every time I read the paper/those old feelings come on/We are waist deep in the Big Muddy and the big fool says to push on." The lyrics could be interpreted as an allegory of Johnson as the "big fool" and the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> as the foreseeable danger. Although the performance was cut from the September 1967 show,<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> after wide publicity<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> it was broadcast when Seeger appeared again on the Smothers' Brothers show in the following January.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the November 15, 1969, <a href="/wiki/Moratorium_to_End_the_War_in_Vietnam" title="Moratorium to End the War in Vietnam">Vietnam Moratorium March</a> on Washington, DC, Seeger led 500,000 protesters in singing <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a>'s song "<a href="/wiki/Give_Peace_a_Chance" title="Give Peace a Chance">Give Peace a Chance</a>" as they rallied across from the White House. Seeger's voice carried over the crowd, interspersing phrases like, "Are you listening, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Nixon</a>?" between the <a href="/wiki/Refrain" title="Refrain">choruses</a> of protesters singing, "All we are saying ... is give peace a chance".<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>Inspired by <a href="/wiki/Woody_Guthrie" title="Woody Guthrie">Woody Guthrie</a>, whose guitar was labeled "This machine kills fascists",<sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=File:Woody_Guthrie.jpg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="File:Woody Guthrie.jpg (page does not exist)">photo</a></sup> Seeger's banjo was emblazoned with the motto "This Machine Surrounds Hate and Forces It to Surrender."<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Documentary_film" title="Documentary film">documentary film</a> <i>The Power of Song</i>, Seeger mentions that he and his family visited North Vietnam in 1972.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Clearwater">Clearwater</span></h3>
<p>Seeger was involved in the environmental organization <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hudson_River_Sloop_Clearwater&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hudson River Sloop Clearwater (page does not exist)">Hudson River Sloop Clearwater</a>, which he co-founded in 1966. This organization has worked since then to highlight <a href="/wiki/Pollution" title="Pollution">pollution</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> and worked to clean it. As part of that effort, the <a href="/wiki/Sloop" title="Sloop">sloop</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sloop_Clearwater&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sloop Clearwater (page does not exist)"><i>Clearwater</i></a></i> was launched in 1969 with its inaugural sail down from <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">Maine</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Street_Seaport_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Street Seaport Museum (page does not exist)">South Street Seaport Museum</a> in New York City, and thence to the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> Amongst the inaugural crew was <a href="/wiki/Don_McLean" title="Don McLean">Don McLean</a>, who co-edited the book <i>Songs and Sketches of the First Clearwater Crew</i>, with sketches by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_B._Allen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas B. Allen (page does not exist)">Thomas B. Allen</a> for which Seeger wrote the foreword.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> Seeger and McLean sang "Shenandoah" on the 1974 <i>Clearwater</i> album. The sloop regularly sails the river with volunteer and professional crew members, primarily conducting environmental education programs for school groups. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Hudson_River_Revival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Hudson River Revival (page does not exist)">Great Hudson River Revival</a> (aka Clearwater Festival) is an annual two-day music festival held on the banks of the Hudson at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Croton_Point_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Croton Point Park (page does not exist)">Croton Point Park</a>. This festival grew out of early fundraising concerts arranged by Seeger and friends to raise money to pay for <i>Clearwater's</i> construction.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pete_Seeger_Clearwater.jpg" title="File:Pete Seeger Clearwater.jpg">File:Pete Seeger Clearwater.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Seeger's album <i>Clearwater Classics</i>. The title alludes to his work with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Clearwater_group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clearwater group (page does not exist)">Clearwater group</a>, working to clean the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Seeger wrote and performed "That Lonesome Valley" about the then-polluted Hudson River in 1969, and his band members also wrote and performed songs commemorating the <i>Clearwater</i>.
</p><p>The 106-foot-long sailboat, <i>Clearwater</i>, was built to conduct science-based environmental education aboard the sailing ship. <i>Clearwater</i> has education programs with many colleges and institutions, including SUNY New Paltz, and Pace University. The sail ship has become recognized for its role in the environmental movement. The Clearwater Festival brings Hudson Valley residents together to enjoy music, their cultural heritage, and support a cause.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_Protection_Agency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental Protection Agency (page does not exist)">Environmental Protection Agency</a> said after his death that "the incredible work" of Seeger and the Clearwater organization helped make the Hudson River cleaner. "His leadership was extraordinary," regional Administrator Judith A. Enck told United Press International.<sup id="cite_ref-upi.com_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-upi.com-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reflection_on_support_for_Soviet_Communism">Reflection on support for Soviet Communism</span></h3>
<p>In 1982, Seeger performed at a benefit concert for <a href="/w/index.php?title=August_31,_1982_demonstrations_in_Poland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="August 31, 1982 demonstrations in Poland (page does not exist)">Poland's Solidarity resistance movement</a>. His biographer <a href="/w/index.php?title=David_King_Dunaway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="David King Dunaway (page does not exist)">David Dunaway</a> considers this the first public manifestation of Seeger's decades-long personal dislike of communism in its Soviet form.<sup id="cite_ref-dunawayp103_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dunawayp103-75">[75]</a></sup> In the late 1980s Seeger also expressed disapproval of violent revolutions, remarking to an interviewer that he was really in favor of incremental change and that "the most lasting revolutions are those that take place over a period of time."<sup id="cite_ref-dunawayp103_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dunawayp103-75">[75]</a></sup> In his autobiography <i>Where Have All the Flowers Gone</i> (1993, 1997, reissued in 2009), Seeger wrote, "Should I apologize for all this? I think so." He went on to put his thinking in context:
</p>
<blockquote>How could <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hitler (page does not exist)">Hitler</a> have been stopped? <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Litvinov" title="Maxim Litvinov">Litvinov</a>, the Soviet delegate to the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> in '36, proposed a worldwide quarantine but got no takers. For more on those times check out pacifist <a href="/wiki/Dave_Dellinger" title="Dave Dellinger" class="mw-redirect">Dave Dellinger</a>'s book, <i>From Yale to Jail&#160;...</i><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> At any rate, today I'll apologize for a number of things, such as thinking that Stalin was merely a "hard driver" and not a "supremely cruel misleader." I guess anyone who calls himself a Christian should be prepared to apologize for the <a href="/wiki/Inquisition" title="Inquisition">Inquisition</a>, the burning of heretics by Protestants, the slaughter of Jews and Muslims by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crusades&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crusades (page does not exist)">Crusaders</a>. White people in the U.S.A. ought to apologize for <a href="/wiki/Indian_removal" title="Indian removal">stealing land from Native Americans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States" title="Slavery in the United States">enslaving blacks</a>. Europeans could apologize for worldwide conquests, Mongolians for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Genghis_Khan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genghis Khan (page does not exist)">Genghis Khan</a>. And supporters of <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Roosevelt</a> could apologize for his support of <a href="/wiki/Somoza_family" title="Somoza family">Somoza</a>, of <a href="/wiki/Dixiecrat" title="Dixiecrat">Southern White Democrats</a>, of <a href="/wiki/Francoist_Spain" title="Francoist Spain">Franco Spain</a>, for putting <a href="/wiki/Japanese_American_internment" title="Japanese American internment">Japanese Americans in concentration camps</a>. Who should my granddaughter Moraya apologize to? She's part African, part European, part Chinese, part Japanese, part Native American. Let's look ahead.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nyt1_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt1-78">[78]</a></sup></blockquote>
<p>In a 1995 interview, however, he insisted that "I still call myself a communist, because communism is no more what Russia made of it than Christianity is what the churches make of it."<sup id="cite_ref-The_Old_Left_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Old_Left-79">[79]</a></sup>
In recent years, as the aging Seeger began to garner awards and recognition for his lifelong activism, he also found himself criticized once again for his opinions and associations of the 1930s and 1940s. In 2006, <a href="/wiki/David_Boaz" title="David Boaz">David Boaz</a>—<a href="/wiki/Voice_of_America" title="Voice of America">Voice of America</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=NPR&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NPR (page does not exist)">NPR</a> commentator and president of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Libertarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Libertarianism (page does not exist)">libertarian</a> <a href="/wiki/Cato_Institute" title="Cato Institute">Cato Institute</a>—wrote an opinion piece in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Guardian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Guardian (page does not exist)">The Guardian</a></i>, entitled "Stalin's Songbird" in which he excoriated <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> for lauding Seeger. He characterized Seeger as "someone with a longtime habit of following the party line" who had only "eventually" parted ways with the CPUSA. In support of this view, he quoted lines from the <a href="/wiki/Almanac_Singers" title="Almanac Singers">Almanac Singers</a>' May 1941 <i>Songs for John Doe</i>, contrasting them darkly with lines supporting the war from <i>Dear Mr. President</i>, issued in 1942, after the United States and the Soviet Union had entered the war.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2007, in response to criticism from a former banjo student—historian <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Radosh" title="Ronald Radosh">Ron Radosh</a>, a former <a href="/wiki/Trotskyite" title="Trotskyite" class="mw-redirect">Trotskyite</a> who now writes for the conservative <i><a href="/wiki/National_Review" title="National Review">National Review</a></i>—Seeger wrote a song condemning Stalin, "Big Joe Blues":<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> "<i>I'm singing about old Joe, cruel Joe. / He ruled with an iron hand. /He put an end to the dreams / Of so many in every land. / He had a chance to make / A brand new start for the human race. / Instead he set it back / Right in the same nasty place. / I got the Big Joe Blues. / Keep your mouth shut or you will die fast. / I got the Big Joe Blues. / Do this job, no questions asked. / I got the Big Joe Blues.</i>"<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> The song was accompanied by a letter to Radosh, in which Seeger stated, "I think you’re right, I should have asked to see the <a href="/wiki/Gulag" title="Gulag">gulags</a> when I was in U.S.S.R [in 1965]."<sup id="cite_ref-nyt1_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt1-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Later_work">Later work</span></h3>
<p>On March 16, 2007, Pete Seeger, his sister <a href="/wiki/Peggy_Seeger" title="Peggy Seeger">Peggy</a>, his brothers <a href="/wiki/Mike_Seeger" title="Mike Seeger">Mike</a> and John, his wife Toshi, and other family members spoke and performed at a symposium and concert sponsored by the <a href="/wiki/American_Folklife_Center" title="American Folklife Center">American Folklife Center</a> in honor of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seeger_family&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seeger family (page does not exist)">Seeger family</a>, held at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Library_of_Congress&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Library of Congress (page does not exist)">Library of Congress</a> in Washington, D.C.,<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> where Pete Seeger had been employed by the Archive of American Folk Song 67 years earlier.
</p><p>In September 2008, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Appleseed_Recordings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Appleseed Recordings (page does not exist)">Appleseed Recordings</a> released <i>At 89</i>, Seeger's first studio album in 12 years. On September 29, 2008, the 89-year-old singer-activist, once banned from commercial TV, made a rare national TV appearance on the <i><a href="/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman" title="Late Show with David Letterman">Late Show with David Letterman</a></i>, singing "Take It From Dr. King".
</p><p>On January 18, 2009, Seeger joined <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen" title="Bruce Springsteen">Bruce Springsteen</a>, grandson <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tao_Rodr%C3%ADguez-Seeger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tao Rodríguez-Seeger (page does not exist)">Tao Rodríguez-Seeger</a>, and the crowd in singing the <a href="/wiki/Woody_Guthrie" title="Woody Guthrie">Woody Guthrie</a> song "<a href="/wiki/This_Land_Is_Your_Land" title="This Land Is Your Land">This Land Is Your Land</a>" in the finale of Barack Obama's Inaugural concert in Washington, D.C.<sup id="cite_ref-Tuscaloosa_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tuscaloosa-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-USAToday_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday-86">[86]</a></sup> The performance was noteworthy for the inclusion of <a href="/wiki/This_Land_Is_Your_Land#Confirmation_of_two_other_verses" title="This Land Is Your Land">two verses</a> not often included in the song, one about a "private property" sign the narrator cheerfully ignores, and the other making a passing reference to a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Depression</a>-era relief office.<sup id="cite_ref-Tuscaloosa_85-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tuscaloosa-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p>On May 3, 2009, at <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Clearwater_Concert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Clearwater Concert (page does not exist)">the Clearwater Concert</a>, dozens of musicians gathered in New York at Madison Square Garden to celebrate Seeger's 90th birthday (which was later televised on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_Broadcasting_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public Broadcasting Service (page does not exist)">PBS</a> during the summer),<sup id="cite_ref-seeger90_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-seeger90-88">[88]</a></sup> ranging from <a href="/wiki/Dave_Matthews" title="Dave Matthews">Dave Matthews</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Mellencamp" title="John Mellencamp">John Mellencamp</a>, <a href="/wiki/Billy_Bragg" title="Billy Bragg">Billy Bragg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen" title="Bruce Springsteen">Bruce Springsteen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Morello" title="Tom Morello">Tom Morello</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eric_Weissberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eric Weissberg (page does not exist)">Eric Weissberg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ani_DiFranco" title="Ani DiFranco">Ani DiFranco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roger_McGuinn" title="Roger McGuinn">Roger McGuinn</a> to <a href="/wiki/Joan_Baez" title="Joan Baez">Joan Baez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richie_Havens" title="Richie Havens">Richie Havens</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joanne_Shenandoah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joanne Shenandoah (page does not exist)">Joanne Shenandoah</a>, <a href="/wiki/R._Carlos_Nakai" title="R. Carlos Nakai">R. Carlos Nakai</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bill_Miller_(musician)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bill Miller (musician) (page does not exist)">Bill Miller</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joseph_Fire_Crow&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joseph Fire Crow (page does not exist)">Joseph Fire Crow</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Margo_Thunderbird&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Margo Thunderbird (page does not exist)">Margo Thunderbird</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Paxton" title="Tom Paxton">Tom Paxton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ramblin%27_Jack_Elliott" title="Ramblin' Jack Elliott">Ramblin' Jack Elliott</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arlo_Guthrie" title="Arlo Guthrie">Arlo Guthrie</a>. Cuban singer-songwriter <a href="/wiki/Silvio_Rodr%C3%ADguez" title="Silvio Rodríguez">Silvio Rodríguez</a> was also invited to appear but his visa was not approved in time by the United States government. Consistent with Seeger's long-time advocacy for environmental concerns, the proceeds from the event benefited the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hudson_River_Sloop_Clearwater&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hudson River Sloop Clearwater (page does not exist)">Hudson River Sloop Clearwater</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-clearwater_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-clearwater-89">[89]</a></sup> a non-profit organization founded by Seeger in 1966, to defend and restore the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>. Seeger's 90th Birthday was also celebrated at <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_College_of_Staten_Island&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The College of Staten Island (page does not exist)">The College of Staten Island</a> on May 4.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>On September 19, 2009 Pete Seeger made his first appearance at the 52nd Monterey Jazz Festival, particularly notable because the festival does not normally feature folk artists.
</p><p>In 2010, still active at the age of 91, Seeger co-wrote and performed the song <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=God%27s_Counting_on_Me,_God%27s_Counting_on_You&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="God's Counting on Me, God's Counting on You (page does not exist)">God's Counting on Me, God's Counting on You</a></i> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lorre_Wyatt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lorre Wyatt (page does not exist)">Lorre Wyatt</a>, commenting on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deepwater_Horizon_oil_spill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deepwater Horizon oil spill (page does not exist)">Deepwater Horizon oil spill</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>On October 21, 2011, at age 92, Pete Seeger was part of a solidarity march with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Occupy_Wall_Street&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Occupy Wall Street (page does not exist)">Occupy Wall Street</a> to Columbus Circle in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> The march began with Seeger and fellow musicians exiting Symphony Space (95th and Broadway), where they had performed as part of a benefit for Seeger's Clearwater organization. Thousands of people crowded Pete Seeger by the time they reached Columbus Circle where he performed with his grandson, Tao Rodriguez-Seeger, <a href="/wiki/Arlo_Guthrie" title="Arlo Guthrie">Arlo Guthrie</a>, David Amram, and other celebrated musicians.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> The event, promoted under the name #OccupyTheCircle, was LiveStreamed, and dubbed by some as "The Pete Seeger March".
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Seeger_at_barnraising.png" title="File:Seeger at barnraising.png">File:Seeger at barnraising.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Seeger looks on as a ceremony concludes marking the raising of the new home winter port in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kingston,_New_York&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kingston, New York (page does not exist)">Kingston, New York</a>, of the Sloop <i>Clearwater,</i> September 15, 2012<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>On December 14, 2012, Seeger performed, along with <a href="/wiki/Harry_Belafonte" title="Harry Belafonte">Harry Belafonte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Browne" title="Jackson Browne">Jackson Browne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_(rapper)" title="Common (rapper)">Common</a> and others, at a concert to bring awareness to the 37-year-long ordeal of Native American Activist <a href="/wiki/Leonard_Peltier" title="Leonard Peltier">Leonard Peltier</a>. The concert was held at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beacon_Theatre_(New_York_City)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beacon Theatre (New York City) (page does not exist)">Beacon Theater</a> in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 9, 2013, Hachette Audio Books issued an audiobook entitled <i>Pete Seeger: The Storm King; Stories, Narratives, Poems</i>. This two-CD spoken-word work was conceived of and produced by noted percussionist <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.allmusic.com/artist/jeff-haynes-mn0000316957">Jeff Haynes</a> and presents Pete Seeger telling the stories of his life against a background of music performed by more than 40 musicians of varied genres.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> The launch of the audiobook was held at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dia:Beacon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dia:Beacon (page does not exist)">Dia:Beacon</a> on April 11, 2013 to an enthusiastic audience of around two hundred people, and featured many of the musicians from the project (among them <a href="/w/index.php?title=Samite_(musician)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Samite (musician) (page does not exist)">Samite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dar_Williams" title="Dar Williams">Dar Williams</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dave_Eggar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dave Eggar (page does not exist)">Dave Eggar</a> and <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.fieldrecorder.com/docs/notes/stearnsbio.htm">Richie Stearns</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Horse_Flies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Horse Flies (page does not exist)">the Horse Flies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natalie_Merchant" title="Natalie Merchant">Natalie Merchant</a>) performing live under the direction of producer and percussionist <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.allmusic.com/artist/jeff-haynes-mn0000316957">Haynes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> April 15, 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sirius_XM_Book_Radio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sirius XM Book Radio (page does not exist)">Sirius XM Book Radio</a> presented the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dia:Beacon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dia:Beacon (page does not exist)">Dia:Beacon</a> concert as a special episode of "Cover to Cover Live with Maggie Linton and Kim Alexander" entitled "Pete Seeger:The Storm King and Friends."<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 9, 2013, one month widowed, Seeger was in New York City for a 400 year commemoration of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Two_Row_Wampum_Treaty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Two Row Wampum Treaty (page does not exist)">Two Row Wampum Treaty</a> between the Iroquois and the Dutch. On an interview he gave that day to <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Now!" title="Democracy Now!">Democracy Now!</a>, Seeger sang <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=N%C3%A2z%C4%B1m_Hikmet_Ran#I_come_and_stand_at_every_door">"I Come and Stand at Every Door"</a> as it was also the 68th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic bombings.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>On September 21, 2013, Pete Seeger performed at <a href="/wiki/Farm_Aid" title="Farm Aid">Farm Aid</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saratoga_Performing_Arts_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saratoga Performing Arts Center (page does not exist)">Saratoga Performing Arts Center</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saratoga_Springs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saratoga Springs (page does not exist)">Saratoga Springs</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York (page does not exist)">New York</a>. Joined by Wille Nelson, Neil Young, John Mellencamp, and Dave Matthews, he sang "This Land Is Your Land"<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> and included a verse he said he had written specifically for the Farm Aid concert.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2>
<p>Seeger died on January 27, 2014, at the age of 94. According to his grandson, Kitama Cahill-Jackson, Seeger died peacefully in his sleep around 9:30 p.m. at New York's <a href="/wiki/NewYork%E2%80%93Presbyterian_Hospital" title="NewYork–Presbyterian Hospital">Presbyterian Hospital</a>, where he had been for six days. Family members were with him at the time of his death. Cahill-Jackson said Seeger was still as active as ever, out chopping wood ten days prior to his death.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>Response and reaction to Seeger's death quickly poured in. <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen" title="Bruce Springsteen">Bruce Springsteen</a> said of Seeger's passing, "I lost a great friend and a great hero last night, Pete Seeger", before performing "<a href="/wiki/We_Shall_Overcome" title="We Shall Overcome">We Shall Overcome</a>" while on tour in <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Africa (page does not exist)">South Africa</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=President_Barack_Obama&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="President Barack Obama (page does not exist)">President Barack Obama</a> noted that Seeger had been called "America's tuning fork" and that he believed in "the power of song" to bring social change.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> "Over the years, Pete used his voice and his hammer to strike blows for workers' rights and civil rights; world peace and environmental conservation, and he always invited us to sing along. For reminding us where we come from and showing us where we need to go, we will always be grateful to Pete Seeger. Michelle and I send our thoughts and prayers to Pete's family and all those who loved him."<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Selected_discography">Selected discography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1966
</td>
<td> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dangerous_Songs!%3F&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dangerous Songs!? (page does not exist)">Dangerous Songs!?</a></i>
</td>
<td> Columbia Records
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1967
</td>
<td> <i>Waist Deep In The Big Muddy And Other Love Songs</i>
</td>
<td> Columbia Records
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1968
</td>
<td> <i>Wimoweh and Other Songs of Freedom and Protest</i>
</td>
<td> Folkways Records
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1973
</td>
<td> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rainbow_Race&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rainbow Race (page does not exist)">Rainbow Race</a></i>
</td>
<td> Columbia Records
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1974
</td>
<td> <i>Banks of Marble and Other Songs</i>
</td>
<td> Folkways Records
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1979
</td>
<td> <i>Circles &amp; Seasons</i>
</td>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Records" title="Warner Bros. Records">Warner Bros. Records</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1980
</td>
<td> <i>God Bless the Grass</i>
</td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Folkways_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Folkways Records (page does not exist)">Folkways Records</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1989
</td>
<td> <i>Traditional Christmas Carols</i>
</td>
<td> <span class="nowrap"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smithsonian_Folkways&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smithsonian Folkways (page does not exist)">Smithsonian Folkways</a></span>
</td></tr>

</td>

</td>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>

<td> 2002
</td>

</td>

<p><sup id="cite_ref-discography1_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-discography1-106">[106]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-discography2_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-discography2-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tribute_albums_and_songs">Tribute albums and songs</span></h2>
<p>In the 1970s, <a href="/wiki/Harry_Chapin" title="Harry Chapin">Harry Chapin</a> released a song dedicated to Seeger called "Old Folkie".{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>In 1998, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Appleseed_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Appleseed Records (page does not exist)">Appleseed Records</a> issued a double-CD tribute album: <i>Where Have All the Flowers Gone: the Songs of Pete Seeger</i>, which includes readings by <a href="/wiki/Studs_Terkel" title="Studs Terkel">Studs Terkel</a> and songs by <a href="/wiki/Billy_Bragg" title="Billy Bragg">Billy Bragg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Browne" title="Jackson Browne">Jackson Browne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eliza_Carthy" title="Eliza Carthy">Eliza Carthy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judy_Collins" title="Judy Collins">Judy Collins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Cockburn" title="Bruce Cockburn">Bruce Cockburn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donovan" title="Donovan">Donovan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ani_DiFranco" title="Ani DiFranco">Ani DiFranco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dick_Gaughan" title="Dick Gaughan">Dick Gaughan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nanci_Griffith" title="Nanci Griffith">Nanci Griffith</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richie_Havens" title="Richie Havens">Richie Havens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indigo_Girls" title="Indigo Girls">Indigo Girls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roger_McGuinn" title="Roger McGuinn">Roger McGuinn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holly_Near" title="Holly Near">Holly Near</a>, <a href="/wiki/Odetta" title="Odetta">Odetta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Paxton" title="Tom Paxton">Tom Paxton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bonnie_Raitt" title="Bonnie Raitt">Bonnie Raitt</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_Simpson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin Simpson (page does not exist)">Martin Simpson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen" title="Bruce Springsteen">Bruce Springsteen</a>, among others.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>In 2001, Appleseed Records released <i>If I Had a Song: The Songs of Pete Seeger, Vol. 2.</i>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>In 2003, Appleseed Records issued the double-CD <i>Seeds: The Songs of Pete Seeger, Volume 3</i>, the final set in its trilogy of releases celebrating Seeger's music.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>In April 2006, <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen" title="Bruce Springsteen">Bruce Springsteen</a> released a collection of folk songs associated with Seeger's repertoire, titled, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Shall_Overcome:_The_Seeger_Sessions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Shall Overcome: The Seeger Sessions (page does not exist)">We Shall Overcome: The Seeger Sessions</a></i> (which contained no songs actually composed by Seeger).{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Springsteen and his band also toured to sellout crowds in a series of concerts based on those sessions.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} He had previously performed the Seeger staple, "We Shall Overcome", on <i>Where Have All the Flowers Gone</i>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tributes">Tributes</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> A proposal was made in 2009 to name the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walkway_Over_the_Hudson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walkway Over the Hudson (page does not exist)">Walkway Over the Hudson</a> in his honor.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> A posthumous suggestion that  Seeger's name be applied to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tappan_Zee_Bridge_Replacement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tappan Zee Bridge Replacement (page does not exist)">replacement Tappan Zee Bridge</a> being built over the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> has been made by local town supervisor, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paul_Feiner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paul Feiner (page does not exist)">Paul Feiner</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-upi.com_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-upi.com-74">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> Seeger's boat, the <a href="/wiki/Sloop" title="Sloop">sloop</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hudson_River_Sloop_Clearwater&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hudson River Sloop Clearwater (page does not exist)">Clearwater</a></i>, is based at <a href="/wiki/Beacon,_New_York" title="Beacon, New York">Beacon, New York</a>, just upriver from the bridge.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span></h2>
<p>Seeger has been the recipient of many awards and recognitions throughout his career, including:
</p>
<ul>
<li> Induction into the <a href="/wiki/Songwriters_Hall_of_Fame" title="Songwriters Hall of Fame">Songwriters Hall of Fame</a> (1972)<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> The <a href="/wiki/Eugene_V._Debs" title="Eugene V. Debs">Eugene V. Debs</a> Award (1979)
</li>
<li> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Letelier-Moffitt_Human_Rights_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Letelier-Moffitt Human Rights Award (page does not exist)">Letelier-Moffitt Human Rights Award</a> (1986)
</li>
<li> The <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award" title="Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award">Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award</a> (1993)<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> The <a href="/wiki/National_Medal_of_Arts" title="National Medal of Arts">National Medal of Arts</a> from the <a href="/wiki/National_Endowment_for_the_Arts" title="National Endowment for the Arts">National Endowment for the Arts</a> (1994)
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_Center_Honors" title="Kennedy Center Honors">Kennedy Center Honor</a> (1994)
</li>
<li> The Harvard Arts Medal (1996)
</li>
<li> The James Smithson Bicentennial Medal (1996)<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> Induction into the <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rock and Roll Hall of Fame">Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a> (1996)
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Traditional_Folk_Album" title="Grammy Award for Best Traditional Folk Album">Grammy Award for Best Traditional Folk Album</a> of 1996 for his record <i>Pete</i> (1997)
</li>
<li> The Felix Varela Medal, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cuba&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cuba (page does not exist)">Cuba</a>'s highest honor for "his humanistic and artistic work in defense of the environment and against racism" (1999)
</li>
<li> The Schneider Family Book Award for his children's picture book <i>The Deaf Musicians</i>. (2007)
</li>
<li> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mid-Hudson_Civic_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mid-Hudson Civic Center (page does not exist)">Mid-Hudson Civic Center</a> Hall of Fame (2008)- Seeger and Arlo Guthrie performed the first public concert at the Poughkeepsie, New York not-for-profit family entertainment venue, close to Seeger's home, in 1976. Grandson Tao Rodríguez-Seeger accepted the Hall of Fame plaque on behalf of his grandfather.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Traditional_Folk_Album" title="Grammy Award for Best Traditional Folk Album">Grammy Award for Best Traditional Folk Album</a> of 2008 for his record <i>At 89</i> (2009)
</li>
<li> The Peace Abbey Courage of Conscience Award<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> for his commitment to peace and social justice as a musician, songwriter, activist, and environmentalist that spans over sixty years. (2008)
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Dorothy_and_Lillian_Gish_Prize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize (page does not exist)">The Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize</a> (2009)
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Musical_Album_for_Children" title="Grammy Award for Best Musical Album for Children">Grammy Award for Best Musical Album for Children</a> of 2010 for his record <i>Tomorrow's Children, Pete Seeger and the Rivertown Kids and Friends</i> (2011)
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_Peabody_Medal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George Peabody Medal (page does not exist)">George Peabody Medal</a> (2013)
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Spoken_Word_Album" title="Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album">Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album</a> of 2013 nomination for <i>Pete Seeger: The Storm King; Stories, Narratives, Poems</i> (2014)<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Quotes">Quotes</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ambox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ambox (page does not exist)">Template:Ambox</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="From_Seeger">From Seeger</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> "Don't let schoolin' get in the way of your education."<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "Some may find them [songs] merely diverting melodies. Others may find them incitements to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Red_Revolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Red Revolution (page does not exist)">Red revolution</a>. And who will say if either or both is wrong? Not I."<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "I like to say I'm more <a href="/wiki/Conservatism" title="Conservatism">conservative</a> than <a href="/wiki/Barry_Goldwater" title="Barry Goldwater">Goldwater</a>. He just wanted to turn the clock back to when there was no income tax. I want to turn the clock back to when people lived in small villages and took care of each other."<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "Technology will save us if it doesn't wipe us out first."<sup id="cite_ref-democracynow_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-democracynow-120">[120]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "I still call myself a communist, because communism is no more what Russia made of it than <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> is what the churches make of it. But if by some freak of history communism had caught up with this country, I would have been one of the first people thrown in jail."<sup id="cite_ref-The_Old_Left_79-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Old_Left-79">[79]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "When I am very hungry, nothing satisfies me more than a heaping plate of <a href="/wiki/Fried_clams" title="Fried clams">fried clams</a> with <a href="/wiki/Tartar_sauce" title="Tartar sauce">tartar sauce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coleslaw" title="Coleslaw">coleslaw</a>, and fries."{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<ul>
<li> "I certainly should apologize for saying that <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stalin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stalin (page does not exist)">Stalin</a> was a hard driver rather than a very cruel leader. I don't speak out about a lot of things. I don't talk about slavery. A lot of white people in America could apologize for stealing land from the Indians and enslaving Africans. Europe could apologize for worldwide conquest. Mongolia could apologize for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Genghis_Khan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genghis Khan (page does not exist)">Genghis Khan</a>. But I think the thing to do is look ahead."<sup id="cite_ref-nyt1_78-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt1-78">[78]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "There is hope for the world."&#160;– in <i>Pete Seeger: The Power of Song</i> (2007).<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "We sang about Alabama 1955, / But since 9-11, we wonder, will this world survive? / The world learned a lesson from Dr. King: / We can survive, we can, we will, and so we sing&#160;– // Don’t say it can’t be done, / The battle's just begun. / Take it from <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King,_Jr." title="Martin Luther King, Jr.">Dr. King</a>, / You too can learn to sing, / So drop the gun."<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "I believe God is everywhere."<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "Singing with children in the schools has been the most rewarding experience of my life."&#160;– Seeger, October 17, 2009, at community concert in Beacon, New York
</li>
<li> "I usually quote <a href="/wiki/Plato" title="Plato">Plato</a>, who said: 'It is very dangerous to allow the wrong kind of music in the republic'."<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="From_others">From others</span></h3>
<p>Jim Musselman (founder of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Appleseed_Recordings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Appleseed Recordings (page does not exist)">Appleseed Recordings</a>), longtime friend and record producer for Pete Seeger:
</p>
<dl>
<dd><i>He was one of the few people who invoked the <a href="/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="First Amendment to the United States Constitution">First Amendment</a> in front of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_Committee_on_Un-American_Activities&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House Committee on Un-American Activities (page does not exist)">House Committee on Un-American Activities</a> (HCUA). Everyone else had said the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fifth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution (page does not exist)">Fifth Amendment</a>, the right against self-incrimination, and then they were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Motion_(legal)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Motion (legal) (page does not exist)">dismissed</a>. What Pete did, and what some other very powerful people who had the guts and the intestinal fortitude to stand up to the committee and say, "I'm gonna invoke the First Amendment, the right of freedom of association...."</i>
</dd>
<dd><i>...I was actually in law school when I read the case of </i>United States v. Seeger<i>, and it really changed my life, because I saw the courage of what he had done and what <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Ten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hollywood Ten (page does not exist)">some other people</a> had done by invoking the First Amendment, saying, "We're all Americans. We can associate with whoever we want to, and it doesn't matter who we associate with." That's what the <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States" title="Founding Fathers of the United States">founding fathers</a> set up democracy to be. So I just really feel it's an important part of history that people need to remember."</i><sup id="cite_ref-democracynow_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-democracynow-120">[120]</a></sup>
</dd>
</dl>
<p><a href="/wiki/Raffi_(musician)" title="Raffi (musician)">Raffi</a>, on his concert video "Raffi on Broadway",{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} about the song "<a href="/wiki/May_There_Always_Be_Sunshine" title="May There Always Be Sunshine">May There Always Be Sunshine</a>":
</p>
<dl>
<dd><i>This song is the one that I first heard Pete Seeger singing. He tells me that it was written by a four-year-old boy in Russia. And it's just got four lines and it's been translated into a number of languages.</i>
</dd>
</dl>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_banjo_players" title="List of banjo players">List of banjo players</a>
</li>

</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tom_Winslow&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tom Winslow (page does not exist)">Tom Winslow</a>&#160;– Clearwater singer and songwriter
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<ul>
<li>Dunaway, David K. <i>How Can I Keep from Singing: The Ballad of Pete Seeger</i>. [McGraw Hill (1981), DaCapo (1990)] Revised Edition. New York: Villard Trade Paperback, 2008 <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0070181500" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-07-018150-0</a>, <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0070181519" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-07-018151-9</a>, <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0306803992" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-306-80399-2</a>, <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0345506081" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-345-50608-1</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tradebit.com/filedetail.php/5191201-david-dunaway">Audio Version</a>
</li>
<li>Dunaway, David K. <i>Pete Seeger: How Can I Keep From Singing</i>. three one-hour radio documentaries, Public Radio International, 2008
</li>
<li>Dunaway, David K. <i>The Pete Seeger Discography.</i> Scarecrow Press: Lanham, MD: Rowman and Littlefield, 2010.
</li>
<li>Forbes, Linda C. "Pete Seeger on Environmental Advocacy, Organizing, and Education in the Hudson River Valley: An Interview with the Folk Music Legend, Author and Storyteller, Political and Environmental Activist, and Grassroots Organizer." <i>Organization &amp; Environment</i>, 17, No. 4, 2004: pp.&#160;513–522.
</li>
<li>Gardner, Elysa. "Seeger: A 'Power' in music, politics." <a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a>, February 27, 2008. p.&#160;8D.
</li>
<li>Seeger, Pete. <i>How to Play the Five-String Banjo</i>, New York: People’s Songs, 1948. 3rd edition, New York: Music Sales Corporation, 1969. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0825600243" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8256-0024-3</a>.
</li>
<li>Tick, Judith. <i>Ruth Crawford Seeger: A Composer's Search for American Music</i>. Oxford University Press, 1997.
</li>
<li>Wilkinson, Alec. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/04/17/060417fa_fact_wilkinson">"The Protest Singer: Pete Seeger and American folk music,"</a> <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</a></i>, April 17, 2006, pp.&#160;44–53.
</li>
<li>Wilkinson, Alec. <i>The Protest Singer: An Intimate Portrait of Pete Seeger</i>. New York: Knopf, 2009.
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_news&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite news (page does not exist)">Template:Cite news</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Dead_link&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Dead link (page does not exist)">Template:Dead link</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> Seeger, Pete, (Edited by Jo Metcalf Schwartz), <i>The Incompleat Folksinger</i>, New York: Simon and Schuster, 1972. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/067120954X" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-671-20954-X</a> (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.peteseeger.net/incompleatfolksinger.htm">excerpts</a>) Also, reprinted in a Bison Book edition, Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1992. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0803292163" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8032-9216-3</a>
</li>
<li> "The Music Man." (profile and interview) In <i>Something to Say: Thoughts on Art and Politics in America</i>, text by Richard Klin, photos by Lily Prince (Leapfrog Press, 2011).
</li>
<li> Seeger, Pete (Edited by Rob and Sam Rosenthal), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.paradigmpublishers.com/Books/BookDetail.aspx?productID=298790"><i>Pete Seeger: In His Own Words</i></a>, Paradigm Publishers, 2012. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1612052185" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1612052185</a>. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781612052182" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-1612052182</a>
</li>
<li> Seeger, Pete (Edited by Ronald D. Cohen and James Capaldi), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://global.oup.com/academic/product/the-pete-seeger-reader-9780199862016;jsessionid=B0E432C11399552C64CC4781B362F5E0?cc=us&amp;lang=en&amp;"><i>The Pete Seeger Reader</i></a>, Oxford University Press, 2014. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780199862016" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 9780199862016</a>
</li>
</ul>

	<h3><label for="searchInput">Search</label></h3>
